_header: God that shaped both heaven and hell
Note: For a similar versions with many identical lines, see 1477.
_description: ‘The Stasyons of Ierusalem’ — in couplets with occasional quatrains

BodAsh61.First Lines:
God that schupe both heuen & helleTo þe lord I make my
                    moneAnd gyne me grace þe sothe to telleOf þe pylgryme Age
                    þat I haue gone…
BodAsh61.Last Lines:
…Off þe lord to haue in myndffor to be hold þi
                    blyssyd face
BodAsh61.Editions:
Horstmann,  Carl. 
             Altenglische Legenden: Neue Folge.
         Heilbronn: Henninger, 1881: 356-66.
Meech,  Sanford Brown,  and  Hope Emily Allen, eds.  
             The Book of Margery Kempe.
EETS
         o.s. 212 (1940); repr. 1961: 288.
Shuffleton,  George. 
             Ashmole 61: A Compilation of Popular Middle English Verse.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Western Michigan University for TEAMS, 2008: 330-48; 547-58; 620-2.

HunHM144.First Lines:
GOd þat made bothe heuen & helleTo the lorde I make my
                    mone…
HunHM144.Last Lines:
…And at oure dethe to haue thi mercy & thi graceThat we in
                    heuyn may haue a place
HunHM144.Note:
Added conclusion, ‘Amen for charite I pray Crist Ihesu haue mery
                    on me’ (f. 80v).
HunHM144.Attributed Title: Here begynnyth the Pilgrymage and the wayes of Ierusalem (f. 67)
